reviewText: Most of us are well short of the level of education and subsequent anatomical knowledge required to successfully perform a heart transplant. Still, who wouldn't mind experiencing the awesome wave of heroic accomplishment that washes over a surgeon each time he or she saves a person's life? Surgeon Simulator 2013, a game from Bossa Studios, won't help you be a surgeon. It won't help you save lives, either. Hell, I'd even go as far as to say it has a negative influence on your personal knowledge of what invasive surgery actually entails. What it does do, almost in spite of itself, is haphazardly simulate the thrill of ripping a man's heart out of his chest and replacing it with another one.Surgeon Simulator 2013 replicates surgery the same way Enviro-Bear 2010 simulates a bear driving a car; with one hand and deliberately obtuse control. You play as Nigel Burke, or, more specifically, you play as Nigel Burke's left hand. Each of Nigel's fingers are controlled with your fingers on the A, W, E, and R keys, respectively, while Nigel's and your thumb is left to the space bar. Yes, that's completely insane, and yet also sort of logical position for your hand on a keyboard.Surgeon Simulator 2013's clumsy control is more of an endearing hook than a frustrating point of contention. It seems impossible, but, like rubbing your stomach and patting your head, an operational degree of control is gained with a bit of practice. Plopping Nigel’s hand down on a scalpel and watching him haphazardly pick it up like a cave man holding a pencil is both effectively hilarious and functionally acceptable. Hovering the hand over an artery and dropping it to replicate some sort of crude sawing motion looks absurd, but typically manages to get the job done. Playing Surgeon Simulator 2013 for a couple hours grants an almost expert level of control, but being a novice is almost more enjoyable simply because of how ridiculous everything appears when swinging Nigel’s dumb hand around the operating table.It helps that Surgeon Simulator 2013’s proposed method of surgery is almost completely unrealistic. Despite being mostly about goofs up to this point, there's a neat little game packed in Surgeon Simulator 2013. If you wreck Bob's guts too much he'll start bleeding, and if he bleeds out completely you'll murder the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and fail the surgery.Spontaneity is perhaps Surgeon Simulator 2013's finest asset. Being physics-based game loaded with a ton of props, it's prone to numerous instances of accidental mishaps. Since Nigel's arms controls like your arm if it had been numb for three years, knocking all of the extraneous crap over on the operating table is a common occurrence. Likewise, accidentally dropping your scalpel, bone saw, or plastic spoon inside Bob's chest cavity is frequently unavoidable. From getting a scalpel lodged in your palm to accidentally administering hallucinogenic drugs on yourself, Surgeon Simulator 2013 is loaded with random and surprising tomfoolery.Obscene humor is the reason to play Surgeon Simulator 2013, and it delivers that asset in spades, but down the line it actually morphs into a legitimate challenge. After failing twenty or whatever times, I was sweating bullets the first time I managed to complete the kidney transplant. The sheer amount of things that could go wrong, not the mention the sloppy control, made for a true feeling of accomplishment upon completion. It's nothing like real surgery, obviously, but I did feel the overwhelming need to high five every one around and celebrate once I finally got it right.Half the fun is mentioning the premise of Surgeon Simulator 2013 to a buddy and then watching him or her come to grips with the outrageous task before them.And there you have it. Surgery Simulator 2013 is a joke, and its creators are well aware of that fact, but it’s effectively the best game about completing surgical procedures with a phantom limb ever made.

reviewText:
Surgeon Simulator is ridiculously stupid yet somehow manages to be frustratingly fun. Your role is simple. Play doctor and transplant specific organs without letting your patient die. Sounds complicated right? Well the game severely dumbs down the process effectively letting you rip out anything you don't need to focus on the task at hand.

Learning the controls is actually half of the fun. You only get one hand in the game, but you have to control that one hand with two hands of your own using both the keyboard and mouse. The mouse moves your wrist and arm and the keyboard grasps your fingers to grab tools and organs. It's quite tricky to get the hang of because it just feels so unnatural and it can be quite a challenge to hold tools at just the right angle to make that precision cut.

Although the title may give a false sense that it showcases some realism, there is no doubt that Surgeon Simulator is designed for purely amusement purposes only. And it certainly excels in the amusement category. An extremely original concept plus very innovative gameplay make this a game worth trying at least once.

reviewText:
Surgeon Simulator is a first person QWOP game. You take the role of a surgeon named Nigel Burke. Mouse movements control your doctor’s hand, up, down, left, right, and rotating. A, W, E, R and space bar are all used to control individual fingers on the hand, this is used to grasp the utensils, The game play consists of the player trying to complete a number of different operations on your patient, the first being something as simple as a heart transplant.

Once completing the first operations, you then unlock different scenarios, such as ambulance operations, ad space operations, which incorporate bumping round tools and zero gravity,

The graphics are nicely presented and everything looks clean and polished, I don't think photo realism graphics would be something I would be looking for in this type of game anyway. The soundtrack is mainly the general hospital/emergency theme tune the whole time, I had to turn it off after the first hour or two as it just grew very repetitive very fast, all of the sound effects in game of the grinding, sawing and squelching are all very nicely produced.

This game is hard, like, hard as nails hard, I am nowhere near completing it, and I have played for almost eleven hours, your hands start to ache if you play any more than an hour due to the intense holding down of the buttons and thought that goes into picking up a single item, it is unbelievable, I did try out using a controller using Pinnacle Gaming Profile (quick shout out to them while I am at it), and this did make the controls a little easier to use, but it was still stupidly difficult.

I haven't found any technical issues, I would think a potato could run Surgeon Simulator; it's a well optimized game.

A lot of the time I spent on this was playing with friends, just playing around seeing how messed up we could get, and that's what this game is all about, just having a laugh and giggle, it's hard to sit down on your own for hours at a time on this game just because of how strenuous it is on your hand and thought process just to pick something up. But I do recommend that people pick it up, just for the novelty value and for some couch gaming with friends.

reviewText:
I have no idea if you are going to like this game. It's a weird, hard to control, bizarre game. People compare it to QWOP and to the extent that it relies on playing twister with your fingers that's true, but it's much more than that. Each surgery is like a puzzle, trying to figure out which tools work and don't, finding the most efficient route through it. Achievements incentivize creative play. I mean, the most amazing thing about the game is that it exists at all, it's so absurd. But I think if you get past the initial curve you'll find a compelling score/time attack game.

I'll also add that if you have people over to your house, non-gamers LOVE watching this. A casual hammer to the skull here, a drill dropped in a chest cavity there, accidentally throwing the replacement heart away. It's all good.

You're looking at 8-10 hours for completion of every surgery with good scores, maybe 12-15 if you want to go to A++ on everything. The developers have also repeatedly updated the game with new free content, so I think it's fair to say that if you're the type that buys games to support a developer, this is a good choice.

reviewText:
Surgeon Simulator, if I were to sum it up, is 20 minutes of hilarious insanity, followed by a few hours of frustration, mixed with the occasional, satisfying, successful procedures.
Surgeon Simulator is packed with hilarious moments of utter chaos and insanity, such as performing dental surgery with a hatchet, bonesaw, and pencil, or trying to figure out the hilariously awkward controls to perform simple tasks like picking up your phone, or putting a floppy disk in a computer. You have probably seen all that on You Tube.
But after about 20 minutes (varies from person to person), but the chaos gets old really quickly. And then comes the frustration.
You'll be trying to actually finish a surgery, only to be constantly pestered by your character's inability to perform simple tasks, such as picking up items, cramming his hand into tight places, putting more than 20 centimeters between his hand and the patient, inability to peek around his arm, and last but not least his spontanious fits of cerebral palsy.
Which is to say that sometimes your character will fail to pick up items despite his hand being straight on top of them when you flex the fingers, the reach of your arm is so short you cannot reach the farthest edges of the operating table, and in surgeries where the patient is upright, you can barely get your hand over your patient's head, making it nigh impossible to avoid smacking your patient in the face with whatever you're wielding. Besides that, your arm will almost constantly be blocking the view of either your tool or the organ you're trying to sever, and you will constantly drop things despite having a firm grip on them.
These arduous controls are what make the game fun for the first twenty minutes of intentional chaos and carnage, but are also what makes the rest of the game time horrible, and filled with unintentional chaos and carnage.
It does have plenty of good humor, though. I particullalartly liked the TF2 easter egg.
I have decided not to recommend it, but this is only because I would not recommend it at its normal price. I bought it during a sale, and that is probably the primary reason I am not overly disappointed with the game.
If you like chaos and mayhem and randomness, then you'll probably have a good time. If you like to get stuff done, then this is really, really not the game for you.

reviewText:
Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a surgical simulation game.
The controls are suitable rudimentary. You use three keys to flex your fingers, and spacebar for the thumb. Left click can be used to move the arm up and down, while holding down the right button controls the rotations. There are items which, when you grasp near them, sort of “stick” to your fingers.
The amount of content in the game is a little sparse, you can finish everything it has to offer in a couple hours. There are 3 main procedures, 3 variants to these operations, and 2 extra missions. After you have completed all of these there is only the fun of goofing around with the game to add to play time.
There are also several bugs, like the hand got stuck in the table and you have to restart the operation. Sometimes the syringe does not work. Also a frustrating thing is that if an item falls a little too far on the table, you have to restart, because you can not reach it anymore.
Surgeon Simulator 2013 is not a brilliant game, but a brilliant joke, in the form of a game.

Poor controls are taken as a core design philosophy and buttressed with any restrictive obstacle that came to mind. This is not the hilarious but humbling exercise of realizing how difficult complicated basic movement really is, this is a constant fight against a game that not only has to struggle to understand what the player wants it to do but also has trouble preventing objects from phasing in and out of each other. The lesson this game has to teach, what it demands of its players, is that they put aside the anger born of uncooperative controls to practice patience and precision in a world that has none. It's quite clever really. Shame all that's left to look back on is annoyance after annoyance, which increases level by level in the name of some sense of progression.

reviewText:
Silly, silly, silly. This game is an incredible amount of fun, though if you're squeamish at the prospect of flying digital guts and blood...well why are you looking at this game?

But in all seriousness, the style is smooth and visually grabbing, the controls only mildly frustrating when you're on a time crunch (Use two hands, Nigel!), and the enjoyment factor is up to extremely satisfying. My favorite bit is that it even includes a side mission related to my favorite game Team Fortress 2, which if you haven't played, do. The menu is also them most uniquely extensive I've seen, and so much fun to interact with. Warning: You may become so distracted you forget there's an actual game attached.

The only time Surgeon Simulator has frustrated me was when I was going for a couple of especially difficult achievements, but even then I still liked it. I mention this because if you have patience issues, you may find less enjoyment in it than I did, but I'd still urge anyone to try this game.

reviewText:
Surgeon Simulator is one of these short joke games where the core of the gameplay is the hilarity that stems from overcoming intentionally awkward controls and buggy physics. You play as a newbie surgeon - or to be more precise, a clearly disembodied hand - who has to successfully complete various surgeries despite being clumsy as all hell.

Don't look for any kind of anatomical accuracy or realism in this game - ripping off the patient's organs and throwing them on the ground just to get to the one organ that needs replacement is a regular practice in the game, and the mission is considered completed if you manage to throw the new organ onto the spot where it's supposed to be. Even if said organ falls out immediately afterwards while the game merrily displays the success screen (which clearly suggests that the patient wasn't going to survive one way or another). The only thing you have to worry about regarding the patient is making sure that the blood level doesn't reach zero. And yes, you can still finish the mission even if the patient is left with as little as 1 ml of blood. This game exists to be a source of dark humor, not to be realistic.

You are given plenty of tools to accomplish various tasks and it's only up to you to decide what is going to be useful. Obligatory scalpels, various saws for cutting bones, drugs that either slow down or speed up the blood flow, and even axes, hammers and drills. Many of them, more often than not, are going to be only a hindrance in your desperate efforts, blocking your way to the actually important tools, bumping into the patient and making him lose blood, or even getting you high. And that's just the beginning.

As I mentioned, the game isn't very long; there is 9 levels total, plus 2 hidden, and the exact time it will take you to complete them for the first time will vary depending on how badly you'll be initially doing. There are 3 kinds of surgeries in 3 kinds of environments, so at some point you'll end up in a situation where, for example, you have to do a brain transplant in an ambulance that rides on a bumpy road, with the objects jumping up at random and the back door opening from time to time. Probably the funniest moment you are going to see in this game is successfully completing said surgery and then watching as the brain you just put in the patient's head falls out right away and ends up on the floor or even on the road. The mission is still accomplished, so who cares!

Surgeon Simulator is the kind of game that you either just can't stand, or love coming back to it despite how badly it frustrates you. And yes, after the initial hilarity wears off and you get better at playing it, you'll most likely start seeing the game's frustrating elements more and more. Probably the biggest one of them is how it can be a pain in the butt to actually grab things; there's NO indication whether you actually grabbed the damn object or not, usually resulting in you spending some time on the ritual of pressing the buttons to grab something and then raising the hand to see if you actually grabbed it.

Another problem is that the game gives you next to no information on how various things work. There is no tutorial at all; the only thing you get is the info on how to control the hand, which is displayed on the computer in the main menu (and the said menu uses the exact same hand mechanics as well, to make matters even better). The rest you either have to figure out yourself (most likely failing numerous times before you successfully complete a surgery at least once) or just Google things up. The game DOES give tips on certain things, but that's only AFTER you completed a surgery, and only if you figure out that you can put floppy disks into the computer in the main menu. And let me tell you, doing so can be frustratingly hard as well, since the computer will only accept them if they're perfectly aligned.

In the end, Surgeon Simulator is a little curiosity that some people will like, and some people will hate. My recommendation is to first play the demo provided by the creators of the game and see how well you'll do in it. If you'll end up loving the absurdity of the game, then I think you'll like the full game as well. But if you'll instead end up getting frustrated and/or freaking out over the patient dying, then I think you're better off giving up on this one.

reviewText:
>> Hilarious, yet challenging: BUY IT! <<

Ever wanted to be a doctor? But studying 6 years before they let you kill people on the table is too long? Can't wait that long? Well here is your solution: Surgeon Simulator 2013 lets you control  a whole left hand (!) with which to save / end the patients life! If you think you got the hang of it: Forget it, here comes the ambulance operation! If the G-forces of the racing ambulance are a mere joke to you: Forget about gravity, operate in space! And now they have even added Alien operations!

This game is really fun to play and really hard to master. The first hour is extremely fun because the game is quite silly. So if it's on sale, go grab it, it's worth a good laugh! Beyond that, you can spend hours trying to improve your performance during operations in terms of blood loss or time elapsed. And there are some other cool achievements to get in this game. For example: Do you think it's hard to flip a spoon 180° and catch it again? Now do it in a clumsy surgeon sim!

I honestly can't compare this game to any other game I've played before, but what I can do is recommend you give it a try!
Because if you don't like it or your surgery is going ♥♥♥♥ up, you can still let off some steam by taking a hammer and bash your patients skull in! =)

Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a fun, quick and casual game that appeals to a vast audience.  It's not to be taken seriously, but the player has to be really skilled if they want to complete all the surgeries.  I enjoyed my short time playing SS2013, but the Ambulance Operations are way too difficult for my skill level, and couldnt even complete the first scenario.
The controls are awkward crappy, I've never encountered such a scheme in my life, but that's the way the developers intended the game to play.  Graphics are exactly as they should be, not too realistic, but bloody enough to still gross people out.  Amount of tools to use doing the operations are also a plus.  Since I have very little knowledge of the medical field, I have no idea what the best instrument for each job is.  I pretty much had to guess which scalpal to sever an artery.
Overall, its a fun game, and if you buy it on a sale, you will get your money's worth.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that you show to your friends, and everyone begs you to let them have a go on it. But the thing is, you don't want to let them have a go because you're too busy hammering away at the patients rib-cage to even notice your friends are in the room.

When you've only got a little while to spare, you'll find yourself opening up this game. Whilst the storyline is a little outrageous, the amount of fun that you'll have getting used to the controls and getting stuck right into a heart transplant (warning: contains no medical accuracy, whatsover!) far outweights the outrageousness.

The developers have given it a bit of a sense of humor too, even the title menu is a game all in it's self! There's secret missions, and hilarious achievements everywhere, waiting to be found. Just for the love of god, don't drop your wristwatch or a scalpel into the patient, it's a bit of a pain to get back out again.

Anyway, usually I'm not a massive indie game fan, but this is utter brilliance. I've seen the price drop super low during the sales for this game, and I bought it myself at the lowest price I've seen yet, but I'd happily pay more than what I already have for this game, and that's saying something!

Surgeon Simulator 2013 is a fun, quick and casual game that appeals to a vast audience.  It's not to be taken seriously, but the player has to be really skilled if they want to complete all the surgeries.  I enjoyed my short time playing SS2013, but the Ambulance Operations are way too difficult for my skill level, and couldnt even complete the first scenario.
The controls are awkward crappy, I've never encountered such a scheme in my life, but that's the way the developers intended the game to play.  Graphics are exactly as they should be, not too realistic, but bloody enough to still gross people out.  Amount of tools to use doing the operations are also a plus.  Since I have very little knowledge of the medical field, I have no idea what the best instrument for each job is.  I pretty much had to guess which scalpal to sever an artery.
Overall, its a fun game, and if you buy it on a sale, you will get your money's worth.

reviewText:
I would recommend buying the base game of Surgeon Simulator if you have been thinking about it. It is great fun and actually quite addicting, plus the achievements for this game are simple yet challenging enough to make you want to complete all of them. Or at least it made me want to try and get them all. The soundtrack is so good that I bought it (available on Bandcamp) and the game itself is really well optimised. So by all means buy the base game.

However,

The new 'Anniversary Edition' content for this game I cannot possibly reccomend. The menus are completely changed to be more touch friendly and less mouse friendly, which is actually quite a big deal when you have to manually push each button with your virtual hand. The 2 new surgeries are pretty finickity and dull compared to the old ones, and for some reason they don't look half as good. Although this could be due to my next point. There is a new extended options menu in the DLC, this gives you all the options you would expect for a standard PC game. But, for some reason the new setting lag the game to crap. On the base game there was low, medium and high graphics settings. On my 3.2 Ghz i7 8GB ram PC I could run the old base game on high without any lag issues or slowing of any sort with no noticable drops in FPS. But with the new DLC the game lags even on the lowest settings, and the highest settings don't look half as good as they used to. This for me is the biggest problem with the DLC, it must have been shipped out in a hurry with little to no optimisation.
